lessonQuiz.question: What is the underlying asset for Nifty Futures?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Nifty Index

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a variant of Nifty Futures?
lessonQuiz.answerText: End-month

lessonQuiz.question: What is the formula for calculating the contract value of Nifty Futures?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Futures Price x Lot Size

lessonQuiz.question: Which measure indicates the cost of executing a trade in a given security?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Impact cost

lessonQuiz.question: What is a key advantage of trading Nifty Futures over individual stock futures?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Diversification

lessonQuiz.question: What is the typical impact cost of round-trip trading Nifty Futures?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Around 0.0082%

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a reason why liquidity is important in futures trading?

options.text: Easier to enter and exit positions

lessonQuiz.answerText: Higher trading fees

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is the earliest reference to the application of derivatives in India?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Arthashastra

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main difference between a futures contract and a forward contract?

options.text: The exchange on which they are traded

lessonQuiz.answerText: The exchange on which they are traded

lessonQuiz.question: When is a futures contract said to be in a cash settlement?

options.text: When the buyer and seller exchange the underlying asset for cash
When the buyer and seller exchange the difference between the contract price and the market price
When the buyer and seller agree to cancel the contract
When the buyer and seller agree to extend the contract

lessonQuiz.answerText: When the buyer and seller exchange the difference between the contract price and the market price

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main advantage of a futures contract over a forward contract?
lessonQuiz.answerText: It is more liquid

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is not a risk associated with a futures contract?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Regulatory risk

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is a key feature of a futures contract?

options.text: It is traded on an exchange

lessonQuiz.answerText: All of the above

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is not a type of futures contract?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Bond futures

lessonQuiz.question: What is the first step in shorting a stock?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Sell the stock first

lessonQuiz.question: When is it profitable to short a stock?

options.text: When the stock price is expected to increase
When the stock price is expected to decrease
When the stock price is expected to remain the same
When the stock price is expected to fluctuate wildly

lessonQuiz.answerText: When the stock price is expected to decrease

lessonQuiz.question: What is the stoploss price in a short trade?

options.text: The price at which you shorted the stock
The price at which you bought back the stock
A price higher than the price at which you shorted the stock
A price lower than the price at which you shorted the stock

lessonQuiz.answerText: A price higher than the price at which you shorted the stock

lessonQuiz.question: Can short positions be carried overnight in the spot market?

options.text: No, they must be closed before the market closes
Yes, for an indefinite period of time

lessonQuiz.answerText: No, they must be closed before the market closes

lessonQuiz.question: What is the margin requirement for shorting futures?

options.text: It is lower than the margin requirement for long futures positions
It is higher than the margin requirement for long futures positions
It is the same as the margin requirement for long futures positions
It depends on the volatility of the underlying asset

lessonQuiz.answerText: It is the same as the margin requirement for long futures positions

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following statements about shorting is true?

options.text: It is a risky strategy that should only be used by experienced traders
It is a low-risk strategy that can be used by any trader
It is a strategy that is not allowed by all brokers
It is a strategy that is only available for stocks

lessonQuiz.answerText: It is a risky strategy that should only be used by experienced traders

lessonQuiz.question: What is a key difference between shorting in the spot market and shorting in the futures market?

options.text: In the spot market, you can only short stocks that you own, while in the futures market you can short any stock
In the spot market, you can only short for a limited period of time, while in the futures market you can short for an indefinite period of time
In the spot market, the margin requirement is higher than in the futures market
In the spot market, you can only short stocks that are listed on the NSE, while in the futures market you can short stocks that are listed on either the NSE or the BSE

lessonQuiz.answerText: In the spot market, you can only short for a limited period of time, while in the futures market you can short for an indefinite period of time

lessonQuiz.question: What is the minimum number of shares that need to be transacted in a futures contract called?
lessonQuiz.answerText: The minimum number of shares that need to be transacted in a futures contract is called one lot.

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a possible outcome after entering into a futures agreement?

options.text: Price of the asset can go up
Price of the asset can go down
Price of the asset can stay the same

lessonQuiz.answerText: The agreed-upon price cannot change once a futures agreement is entered into.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the process of transferring an existing futures position to someone else called?
lessonQuiz.answerText: The process of transferring an existing futures position to someone else is called square off.

lessonQuiz.question: Which part of the body do we need to move to cut something?
lessonQuiz.answerText: The arm is used to cut, throw, or lift something.

lessonQuiz.question: What instrument is used to measure temperature?
lessonQuiz.answerText: A thermometer is specifically designed to measure temperature.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the term used for a person who rides a bicycle?
lessonQuiz.answerText: A cyclist is someone who rides a bicycle.

lessonQuiz.question: What instrument is used to measure the speed of wind?
lessonQuiz.answerText: An anemometer is an instrument specifically designed to measure the speed of wind.

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a key risk associated with forward contracts?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Credit risk is typically associated with loan agreements, not forward contracts.

lessonQuiz.question: What is a key difference between a futures contract and a forward contract?

options.text: Futures contracts are traded on exchanges, while forward contracts are traded over-the-counter
Futures contracts are standardized, while forward contracts are customized
Futures contracts are more liquid than forward contracts

lessonQuiz.answerText: All of the options listed are key differences between futures and forward contracts.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of a margin in a futures contract?

options.text: To cover potential losses if the price of the underlying asset moves against the trader
To guarantee the performance of the contract
To generate income for the broker

lessonQuiz.answerText: The margin is used as collateral to cover potential losses if the price of the underlying asset moves against the trader.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the relationship between the spot price and the futures price of an asset?

options.text: The futures price is always higher than the spot price
The spot price is always higher than the futures price
The futures price generally follows the spot price
The relationship between the spot price and the futures price is unpredictable

lessonQuiz.answerText: The futures price generally follows the spot price, as traders use futures contracts to hedge against price risk or to speculate on future price movements.

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of using futures contracts?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Futures contracts do not guarantee profit. Profitability depends on the trader's ability to accurately predict future price movements.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of a standardized futures contract?

options.text: To ensure that all contracts are traded on the same terms
To make it easier for traders to compare and hedge contracts
To reduce the risk of counterparty default

lessonQuiz.answerText: Standardization serves all of the purposes listed.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the role of a clearinghouse in the futures market?

options.text: To act as an intermediary between buyers and sellers
To guarantee the performance of contracts
To collect and distribute margin payments

lessonQuiz.answerText: The clearinghouse plays a key role in ensuring the smooth functioning of the futures market by performing all of the functions listed.

lessonQuiz.question: According to the passage, what is the primary reason for charging margins?

options.text: To generate revenue for the trading firm
To offset the risk of counterparty default
To mitigate the impact of market volatility

lessonQuiz.answerText: To offset the risk of counterparty default

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following pieces of information is typically NOT provided to the RMS system when placing a trade?

options.text: The desired price level for the trade

lessonQuiz.answerText: The stoploss point

lessonQuiz.question: What type of product is used to convey information about the trade duration and stoploss to the RMS system?
lessonQuiz.answerText: BO

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of using the BO product type?

options.text: The ability to specify target and stoploss prices
Reduces the risk of being stopped out due to market volatility

lessonQuiz.answerText: Reduces the risk of being stopped out due to market volatility

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main purpose of using a trailing stoploss technique?

options.text: To reduce the risk of losses
To lock in profits while the market moves in your favor
To eliminate the need for manual stoploss adjustments
To increase the chances of making a profit

lessonQuiz.answerText: To lock in profits while the market moves in your favor

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is true about NRML product type?

options.text: It is the most suitable for intraday trading
It conveys information about the trade duration and stoploss to the RMS system
It requires the lowest amount of margin
It is only available for futures contracts

lessonQuiz.answerText: It conveys information about the trade duration and stoploss to the RMS system

lessonQuiz.question: What is the full form of RMS?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Risk Management System

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor included in the futures pricing formula?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Margin requirements are not included in the futures pricing formula.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the term used to describe a situation where the futures price is higher than the spot price?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Premium is the term used to describe a situation where the futures price is higher than the spot price.

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is an example of a spread trade?

options.text: Buying a stock and selling a call option on the same stock
Buying a futures contract and selling a spot contract for the same underlying asset
Buying a bond and selling a treasury bill

lessonQuiz.answerText: Buying a futures contract and selling a spot contract for the same underlying asset is an example of a spread trade.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main assumption made when implementing a calendar spread?

options.text: The spread between the two futures contracts will remain constant.
The price of the underlying asset will remain stable.
The risk-free rate will remain unchanged.

lessonQuiz.answerText: The main assumption made when implementing a calendar spread is that the basis will narrow down.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the term for the difference between the futures price and the spot price?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Spread is the term for the difference between the futures price and the spot price.

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a contango market?

options.text: Futures prices are higher than spot prices
The spread between futures and spot prices is widening
Traders are expecting the price of the underlying asset to rise
The cost of carry is negative

lessonQuiz.answerText: The cost of carry is positive in a contango market, not negative.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of a cash and carry arbitrage?

options.text: To profit from the difference between the futures price and the spot price
To speculate on the direction of the market

lessonQuiz.answerText: The purpose of a cash and carry arbitrage is to profit from the difference between the futures price and the spot price.

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following statements about leverage in futures trading is true?

options.text: Leverage allows traders to enter into large transactions with a small amount of capital
Leverage guarantees profits in futures trading
Leverage is only available in spot market transactions
Leverage has no impact on the potential return of a futures trade

lessonQuiz.answerText: Leverage allows traders to enter into large transactions with a small amount of capital

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main advantage of using leverage in futures trading?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Increased profit potential

lessonQuiz.question: What is the formula for calculating leverage in futures trading?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Leverage = Contract Value / Margin

lessonQuiz.question: What is the payoff structure of a futures instrument?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Linear

lessonQuiz.question: What is the relationship between the profit made by a buyer in a futures trade and the loss incurred by the seller?

options.text: They are equal in magnitude but opposite in sign
They are equal in both magnitude and sign
The buyer's profit is always greater than the seller's loss

lessonQuiz.answerText: They are equal in magnitude but opposite in sign

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following factors affects the margin requirement for a futures trade?

options.text: Term to maturity of the futures contract

lessonQuiz.answerText: Volatility of the underlying asset

lessonQuiz.question: What is a zero-sum game in futures trading?

options.text: A situation where the total profit made by all participants is zero
A situation where the total loss incurred by all participants is zero
A situation where the total profit made by buyers is equal to the total loss incurred by sellers
A situation where the total loss incurred by buyers is equal to the total profit made by sellers

lessonQuiz.answerText: A situation where the total profit made by buyers is equal to the total loss incurred by sellers

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of Zerodha's margin calculator?

options.text: To calculate the margin required for a futures contract
To calculate the profit and loss on a futures trade
To compare the margins of different futures contracts

lessonQuiz.answerText: To calculate the margin required for a futures contract

lessonQuiz.question: What is the formula for calculating the initial margin?

options.text: Initial Margin = SPAN Margin + Exposure Margin
Initial Margin = SPAN Margin - Exposure Margin

lessonQuiz.answerText: Initial Margin = SPAN Margin + Exposure Margin

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT an option available in the Margin Calculator?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Options

lessonQuiz.question: What is the difference between the current month contract and the mid-month contract?

options.text: The current month contract expires on the last trading day of the current month, while the mid-month contract expires on the last trading day of the following month.
The current month contract expires on the first trading day of the following month, while the mid-month contract expires on the last trading day of the following month.
The current month contract expires on the last trading day of the current month, while the mid-month contract expires on the last trading day of the same month.
The current month contract expires on the first trading day of the following month, while the mid-month contract expires on the first trading day of the same month.

lessonQuiz.answerText: The current month contract expires on the last trading day of the current month, while the mid-month contract expires on the last trading day of the following month.

lessonQuiz.question: What is a calendar spread?

options.text: A strategy involving buying a certain month contract and selling another month contract simultaneously for the same underlying.
A strategy involving buying two different month contracts for the same underlying.
A strategy involving selling two different month contracts for the same underlying.
A strategy involving buying a futures contract and selling an options contract for the same underlying.

lessonQuiz.answerText: A strategy involving buying a certain month contract and selling another month contract simultaneously for the same underlying.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main advantage of a calendar spread?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Reduced margin requirements

lessonQuiz.question: When does a futures contract expire?

options.text: On the last trading day of the month in which it is issued.
On the last trading day of the following month.
On the last trading day of the quarter in which it is issued.
On the last trading day of the year in which it is issued.

lessonQuiz.answerText: On the last trading day of the month in which it is issued.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the name of the margin required to cover potential losses on a futures contract?
lessonQuiz.answerText: All of the above

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is **NOT** an advantage of using margins in futures trading?

options.text: Ability to take on larger positions

lessonQuiz.answerText: Reduced risk of losses

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of marking to market (M2M) in futures trading?

options.text: To adjust the value of futures contracts based on daily price fluctuations
To determine the margin requirement for a futures contract
To calculate the total profit or loss on a futures contract
To establish the settlement price for a futures contract

lessonQuiz.answerText: To adjust the value of futures contracts based on daily price fluctuations

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following components does **NOT** make up the initial margin for a futures trade?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Maintenance margin

lessonQuiz.question: What is the function of SPAN margin in futures trading?

options.text: To cover potential losses from price fluctuations
To ensure that traders can meet their financial obligations
To limit the amount of leverage that can be used
To determine the settlement price of a futures contract

lessonQuiz.answerText: To ensure that traders can meet their financial obligations

lessonQuiz.question: What happens when the cash balance in a trading account falls below the maintenance margin?

options.text: The broker issues a margin call
The trader's positions are automatically closed
The trader is penalized with a fine
Nothing, the trader can continue to hold their positions

lessonQuiz.answerText: The broker issues a margin call

lessonQuiz.question: If a trader purchases 1000 shares of a futures contract at ₹100 per share, and the contract multiplier is 100, what is the total contract value?
What is the relationship between futures trading and zero-sum games?

options.text: Futures trading is a zero-sum game because the total amount of money lost by losing traders is equal to the total amount of money gained by winning traders.
Futures trading is not a zero-sum game because the exchange itself makes a profit from transaction fees.
Futures trading is a zero-sum game because the buyer of a futures contract always loses money.
Futures trading is not a zero-sum game because the seller of a futures contract always loses money.

lessonQuiz.answerText: Futures trading is a zero-sum game because the total amount of money lost by losing traders is equal to the total amount of money gained by winning traders.

lessonQuiz.question: What was the main reason behind SEBI making physical delivery of stocks for all stock F&O contracts mandatory?

options.text: To increase liquidity in the market
To reduce volatility in individual stocks
To make trading in F&O contracts more profitable

lessonQuiz.answerText: To reduce volatility in individual stocks

lessonQuiz.question: What is the difference between cash settlement and physical settlement in F&O contracts?

options.text: In cash settlement, buyers and sellers settle their position in cash, while in physical settlement, they have to take delivery of the underlying security.
In physical settlement, buyers and sellers settle their position in cash, while in cash settlement, they have to take delivery of the underlying security.
There is no difference between cash settlement and physical settlement.
Physical settlement is only applicable to futures contracts, while cash settlement is applicable to both futures and options contracts.

lessonQuiz.answerText: In cash settlement, buyers and sellers settle their position in cash, while in physical settlement, they have to take delivery of the underlying security.

lessonQuiz.question: When did SEBI make physical delivery of stocks for all stock F&O contracts mandatory?
lessonQuiz.answerText: April 11, 2018

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of introducing additional margins for F&O positions closer to expiry?

options.text: To reduce the risk of default by traders
To increase the cost of trading in F&O contracts
To prevent excessive speculation in individual stocks
To encourage traders to close their positions before expiry

lessonQuiz.answerText: To reduce the risk of default by traders

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of physical settlement obligation?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Rollover

lessonQuiz.question: How are netted-off positions handled during physical settlement?

options.text: They are combined and settled as a single position.
They are ignored and do not affect the settlement process.
They are sold off before expiry to avoid physical settlement.

lessonQuiz.answerText: They are combined and settled as a single position.

lessonQuiz.question: Which type of stock F&O contracts are subject to physical settlement?

options.text: Only futures contracts with an expiry date within the next 30 days

lessonQuiz.answerText: Both futures and options contracts

lessonQuiz.question: What is the primary purpose of hedging in the market context?

options.text: Protect a position against adverse market movements
Increase the potential return on investment
Reduce the overall risk of a portfolio
Speculate on the future direction of the market

lessonQuiz.answerText: Reduce the overall risk of a portfolio

lessonQuiz.question: Which type of risk can be hedged?
lessonQuiz.answerText: Systematic risk

lessonQuiz.question: What is the most common method used to hedge a single stock position?

options.text: Buying a futures contract for the same stock
Selling a futures contract for the same stock
Buying a put option for the same stock
Selling a call option for the same stock

lessonQuiz.answerText: Selling a futures contract for the same stock

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of beta in calculating the optimal hedge ratio for a portfolio?

options.text: To measure the stock's volatility relative to the market
To determine the correlation between the stock and the market
To estimate the expected return of the stock

lessonQuiz.answerText: To measure the stock's volatility relative to the market

lessonQuiz.question: What is the drawback of using Nifty futures to hedge a portfolio?

options.text: It may not perfectly hedge the portfolio's systematic risk
It is only available for stocks that are included in the Nifty index
It can be expensive to maintain a fully hedged position
It is not suitable for hedging portfolios with low correlation to the Nifty index

lessonQuiz.answerText: It may not perfectly hedge the portfolio's systematic risk

lessonQuiz.question: What is the difference between a perfect hedge and an imperfect hedge?

options.text: A perfect hedge completely eliminates all risk, while an imperfect hedge reduces but does not eliminate risk.
An imperfect hedge completely eliminates all risk, while a perfect hedge reduces but does not eliminate risk.
A perfect hedge and an imperfect hedge are the same thing.
There is no such thing as a perfect hedge.

lessonQuiz.answerText: A perfect hedge completely eliminates all risk, while an imperfect hedge reduces but does not eliminate risk.

lessonQuiz.question: What is the role of futures in hedging?

options.text: To create a position that is opposite to the position being hedged
To reduce the volatility of a portfolio
To speculate on the future direction of the market

lessonQuiz.answerText: To create a position that is opposite to the position being hedged

lessonQuiz.question: What does Open Interest (OI) represent?

options.text: The number of buyers in the market
The current number of outstanding contracts
The total traded volume for the day
The difference between buyers and sellers

lessonQuiz.question: When does OI increase?
When does OI decrease?

options.text: When a contract is bought back
When a contract is sold short

lessonQuiz.question: What does a large difference between OI and Volume indicate?

options.text: There is strong buying or selling pressure
The market is about to reverse

lessonQuiz.question: How can OI be used to identify potential trend reversals?

options.text: Look for a divergence between OI and price
Compare OI to its historical average
Calculate the ratio of OI to Volume
Use OI to predict future price movements

lessonQuiz.question: What happens to OI when there is a transfer of contracts from one party to another?
What does a high OI indicate?
